ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This class is quite useful for its specific purpose and intended audience! It was also intresteting and fun!
Great in-depth introduction to social theory. I understand the decision to focus on 3 authors only was a new development and I think it works very well.
This is an essential course for any anthropology graduate student, even if it were not already required. The material overlaps well with 500-01 and was an important introduction into social theory.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course deepened my knowledge a lot! It gave me a theoretical foundation for my discipline and my own research, and a foundation for broader conversations in my field.
The course provided a comprehensive background of the most influential theorists in social theory which is already proving useful in other classes.

I can't really answer this at this point having only finished one semester, but I have already come across Weber, Marx, and Durkheim in several other academic contexts and over the course of my nascent research so I feel confident that this course provided me with a needed foundation for my future studies.
As mentioned above, I cannot imagine an anthropology graduate program without this course. It was an absolutely essential introduction to social theory.
